item.title: How I Built This Blog in One Day with Zero Coding Skills
item.description:
Today I built this entire blog. From scratch. With zero coding skills.

No, really. I didn’t know what Jekyll was. I’d never written HTML or CSS. I couldn’t tell you the difference between a layout and an include. But here we are â€” you’re reading this on my fully functional, professionally designed blog hosted on GitHub Pages.

How? GitHub Copilot.

What We Built Together

In a single conversation, GitHub Copilot helped me create a complete blog platform. Here’s the technical breakdown:

The Frontend

  • 700+ lines of CSS with custom properties for theming
  • CSS masonry grid using column-count â€” responsive from 1 column (mobile) to 5 columns (4K displays)
  • Dark/light theme toggle with localStorage persistence
  • Real-time search and filtering in vanilla JavaScript

The Infrastructure

  • Jekyll static site generator for Markdown-to-HTML conversion
  • Three layout templates: default.html, post.html, home.html
  • Reusable components in _includes/ for the sidebar navigation
  • Data-driven categories via _data/categories.yml

SEO & Social

  • Open Graph meta tags for Facebook/LinkedIn previews
  • Twitter Card markup for rich tweet embeds
  • Semantic HTML5 structure for accessibility
  • jekyll-seo-tag plugin for automated meta generation

The File Structure 

1
2
3
4
5
6
7

_config.yml          # Jekyll configuration
_layouts/            # HTML templates with Liquid syntax
_includes/           # Reusable components
_posts/              # Markdown blog posts
_data/               # YAML data files
css/styles.css       # All styles (700+ lines)
js/main.js           # Theme, search, filters (130+ lines)

All of this from someone who didn’t know what any of these terms meant this morning.

Let me walk you through how it happened.

Step 1: “I Want to Host This on GitHub Pages”

I started with a single HTML file â€” a template I found online. My first request was simple:

“Please make all necessary changes to host this on a GitHub.io page”

Copilot immediately:

  • Added SEO meta tags
  • Set up Open Graph for social sharing
  • Created the necessary files for GitHub Pages deployment

I didn’t have to Google anything. I just asked.

Step 2: “The Design Looks Weird on My Monitor”

My ultrawide monitor made the layout look stretched. I mentioned it:

“The design doesn’t look fully responsive for wide screen displays”

Copilot added media queries for 1920px+ and 2560px+ screens, creating a 4-5 column grid that actually uses the screen real estate. I don’t even know what a “media query” is, but my blog looks great now.

Step 3: “Can We Make This More Professional?”

Everything was in one giant file. I asked:

“Can you create a professional file structure?”

Within minutes, Copilot reorganized everything:

1
2
3
4

css/styles.css      â†’ All styles in one place
js/main.js          â†’ Theme toggle, search, filters
posts/              â†’ Individual blog posts
assets/             â†’ Images and icons

Clean. Organized. Professional.

Step 4: “Writing HTML Is Hard”

Here’s where the magic really happened. I said:

“Writing blog posts in HTML format looks quite complicated. What is needed to use markdown files as the content source?”

Copilot explained four different approaches and recommended Jekyll â€” a tool that converts simple Markdown files into beautiful HTML pages. When I agreed, it:

  1. Created the Jekyll configuration file
  2. Built three layout templates
  3. Set up reusable components
  4. Converted all my posts to Markdown format
  5. Updated the documentation

Now I write posts like this:

1
2
3
4
5
6
7

---
title: "My Post Title"
date: 2026-02-12
category: guide
---

Just write in plain text with **bold** and *italics*.

And Jekyll turns it into a beautiful blog post. No HTML required.

What I Learned

You don’t need to know how to code to build something amazing. You need to:

  1. Know what you want â€” Have a clear vision
  2. Ask clearly â€” Describe your problem, not the solution
  3. Iterate â€” Each improvement builds on the last
  4. Trust the process â€” AI tools like Copilot know what they’re doing

The Numbers

  • Time spent: One afternoon
  • Lines of code I wrote: 0
  • Lines of code Copilot wrote: 1,000+
  • Google searches: 0
  • Stack Overflow visits: 0
  • Frustration level: Minimal

Try It Yourself

If you’ve been putting off starting a blog because “you’re not technical enough” â€” stop. Here’s what you need:

  1. VS Code with GitHub Copilot
  2. A GitHub account (free)
  3. An idea of what you want to build

That’s it. Start a conversation. Describe what you want. Let AI do the heavy lifting.

The barrier to entry for building on the web has never been lower. The only question is: what will you build?

This post was written on the same day I built this blog. The irony of documenting the journey in the tool that made it possible is not lost on me. ðŸ˜Š

This article provides a comprehensive reference for Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files. Use this as a quick reference when writing blog posts.

Headings

The following HTML <h1>â€”<h6> elements represent six levels of section headings. <h1> is the highest section level while <h6> is the lowest.

Paragraph

Regular paragraphs are simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated by one or more blank lines. Normal paragraphs should not be indented with spaces or tabs.

This is a second paragraph demonstrating how text flows naturally. You can write as much as you need, and the text will wrap automatically.

Emphasis

Use asterisks or underscores for emphasis:

  • This text is italicized
  • This is also italicized
  • This text is bold
  • This is also bold
  • This text is bold and italic
  • This text is strikethrough

Blockquotes

The blockquote element represents content that is quoted from another source.

item.title: Rich Content & Shortcodes Guide
item.description:
This guide covers the various shortcodes and rich content features available in the Hugo Stack theme. Shortcodes extend Markdown with powerful embedding and formatting capabilities.

Quote Shortcode

The quote shortcode displays formatted quotes with author attribution.

Imagination is more important than knowledge. Knowledge is limited. Imagination encircles the world.

â€• Albert Einstein, The World As I See It

Usage 

1
2
3

{{< quote author="Author Name" source="Source Title" url="https://example.com" >}}
Your quote content here.
{{< /quote >}}

YouTube Videos

Embed YouTube videos using Hugo’s built-in shortcode.

Usage 

1

{{< youtube VIDEO_ID >}}

Video Shortcode

Embed self-hosted or remote video files.

Usage 

1

{{< video src="https://example.com/video.mp4" >}}

You can also use multiple sources for browser compatibility:

1

{{< video src="video.webm" autoplay="true" loop="true" muted="true" >}}

Mermaid Diagrams

Stack theme supports Mermaid diagrams out of the box. Simply use a code block with the mermaid language.

Flowchart 

  graph TD;
    A[Start] --> B{Decision};
    B -->|Yes| C[Do something];
    B -->|No| D[Do something else];
    C --> E[End];
    D --> E;

Sequence Diagram 

  sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Server
    participant Database
    
    User->>Server: Request data
    Server->>Database: Query
    Database-->>Server: Return results
    Server-->>User: Send response

Gantt Chart 

  gantt
    title Project Timeline
    dateFormat  YYYY-MM-DD
    section Planning
    Research           :a1, 2026-01-01, 30d
    Design             :after a1, 20d
    section Development
    Implementation     :2026-02-20, 45d
    Testing            :2026-04-01, 15d

Class Diagram 

  classDiagram
    Animal <|-- Duck
    Animal <|-- Fish
    Animal : +int age
    Animal : +String gender
    Animal: +isMammal()
    Animal: +mate()
    class Duck{
        +String beakColor
        +swim()
        +quack()
    }
    class Fish{
        -int sizeInFeet
        -canEat()
    }

GitLab Snippets

Embed code snippets from GitLab.

Usage 

1

{{< gitlab SNIPPET_ID >}}

Gist Embedding

Embed GitHub Gists using Hugo’s built-in shortcode.

Usage 

1

{{< gist USERNAME GIST_ID >}}

Twitter/X Embedding

Embed tweets (note: may require additional configuration).

Usage 

1

{{< tweet user="username" id="TWEET_ID" >}}

Figure Shortcode

Enhanced image display with captions and links.

1

{{< figure src="/images/photo.jpg" caption="A sample figure with caption" >}}

Usage 

1
2
3
4

{{< figure src="/images/photo.jpg" 
    caption="Image caption here" 
    alt="Alt text"
    link="https://example.com" >}}

Highlight Shortcode

Syntax highlighting with line numbers and highlighting specific lines.

1
2
3
4

7

package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    fmt.Println("Hello, World!")
    fmt.Println("This line is highlighted")
}

Usage 

1
2
3

{{< highlight language "options" >}}
Your code here
{{< /highlight >}}

Options include:

  • linenos=table - line numbers in a table
  • linenostart=10 - start line numbers at 10
  • hl_lines=3 5-7 - highlight specific lines

Instagram Embedding

Embed Instagram posts.

Usage 

1

{{< instagram POST_ID >}}

Vimeo Videos

Embed Vimeo videos.

Usage 

1

{{< vimeo VIDEO_ID >}}

Param Shortcode

Display site parameters in your content.

The site title is: Rich Content & Shortcodes Guide

Ref and Relref

Create links to other pages in your site.

Usage 

1

[Relative link]({{< relref "about.md" >}})

Tips for Using Shortcodes

  1. Escape shortcodes in documentation by using /* and */ inside the delimiters
  2. Combine shortcodes with Markdown for richer content
  3. Check the theme docs for additional shortcodes specific to Stack theme
  4. Test locally before publishing to ensure embeds display correctly

For more information, see the Hugo Shortcodes Documentation and Stack Theme Documentation.

item.title: Why 80% of AI Projects Fail â€” And How Yours Can Succeed
item.description:
Based on RAND Corporation Research Report (RRA2680-1)

The Hard Truth About AI Project Failure Rates

Here’s a sobering statistic that should make every tech leader pause: more than 80% of AI projects fail â€” that’s twice the failure rate of traditional IT projects!

RAND Corporation researchers interviewed 65 data scientists and engineers with 5+ years of experience to uncover why so many AI initiatives crash and burn. The findings are eye-opening â€” and more importantly, entirely preventable.

The 5 Root Causes of AI Project Failure

1. Miscommunication About the Problem

The #1 killer of AI projects? Teams don’t actually understand â€” or can’t clearly communicate â€” what problem they’re trying to solve.

“Industry stakeholders often misunderstand â€” or miscommunicate â€” what problem needs to be solved using AI.”

Before writing a single line of code, make sure everyone is aligned on the why.

2. Insufficient Training Data

You can’t train an effective AI model without quality data. Period.

Many organizations dive into AI projects without:

  • Enough data volume
  • Proper data quality
  • Relevant data types

No data = No AI magic

3. Chasing Shiny Technology

Are you solving a real problem… or just playing with the latest tech?

“AI projects fail because the organization focuses more on using the latest and greatest technology than on solving real problems for their intended users.”

Technology should serve the mission â€” not the other way around!

4. Infrastructure Gaps

Even brilliant AI models fail when organizations lack:

  • Proper data governance
  • Deployment pipelines
  • Scalable infrastructure

Building AI without infrastructure is like buying a Ferrari without a road to drive it on.

5. Problems Too Difficult for AI

Sometimes the technology is applied to problems that are simply too difficult for current AI capabilities to solve. Not every problem is a good fit for AI solutions.

How to Make Your AI Projects Succeed

The good news? Each of these failure modes is entirely preventable. Stay tuned for our follow-up post on expert recommendations for AI project success.

Key Takeaways

  • Align first, build second â€” Get everyone on the same page about the problem
  • Data is everything â€” Invest in data quality and quantity before model development
  • Problem over technology â€” Choose tools that fit the problem, not the other way around
  • Build the foundation â€” Infrastructure investments pay dividends
  • Know AI’s limits â€” Some problems aren’t suited for AI solutions

item.title: Why 80% of AI Projects Fail: The Five Root Causes You Need to Know
item.description:
Based on RAND Corporation Research Report RRA2680-1

Artificial Intelligence promises transformative results, yet by some estimates, more than 80 percent of AI projects fail â€” twice the rate of failure for IT projects that do not involve AI. RAND Corporation researchers interviewed 65 data scientists and engineers with at least five years of experience to uncover why.

Here are the five leading root causes of AI project failure:

1. Misunderstanding the Problem

Industry stakeholders often misunderstand â€” or miscommunicate â€” what problem needs to be solved using AI. When teams don’t have clarity on the actual business problem, they build solutions that don’t address real needs.

Without a shared understanding of the problem, even the most sophisticated AI system will fail to deliver value.

2. Insufficient Training Data

Many AI projects fail because the organization lacks the necessary data to adequately train an effective AI model. Machine learning models are only as good as the data they learn from. Without sufficient quality data, models cannot learn the patterns needed to make accurate predictions.

3. Technology Over Problem-Solving

In some cases, AI projects fail because the organization focuses more on using the latest and greatest technology than on solving real problems for their intended users. The allure of cutting-edge tools can distract teams from the fundamental goal: delivering practical solutions.

4. Inadequate Infrastructure

Organizations might not have adequate infrastructure to manage their data and deploy completed AI models, which increases the likelihood of project failure. Even a well-trained model is useless if it cannot be effectively deployed and maintained in production environments.

5. Problems Too Difficult for AI

Sometimes, AI projects fail because the technology is applied to problems that are too difficult for AI to solve. Not every problem is a good fit for AI solutions. Some challenges require human judgment, lack sufficient data patterns, or involve too many unpredictable variables.

The Bottom Line

Understanding these root causes is the first step toward building successful AI projects. Before embarking on your next AI initiative, honestly assess whether your organization:

  • Has clearly defined and communicated the problem
  • Possesses sufficient, high-quality training data
  • Is focused on solving real problems (not just using new technology)
  • Has the infrastructure to support AI deployment
  • Is tackling a problem that AI can realistically solve

item.title: How to Make Your AI Projects Succeed: Expert Recommendations
item.description:
Based on RAND Corporation Research Report RRA2680-1

With AI project failure rates exceeding 80%, organizations need actionable strategies to improve their odds of success. RAND Corporation researchers synthesized insights from 65 experienced data scientists and engineers to develop practical recommendations for both industry and academia.

Recommendations for Industry Leaders

1. Ensure Technical Staff Understand the Project Purpose

Misunderstandings and miscommunications about the intent and purpose of the project are the most common reasons for AI project failure.

Bridge the gap between business stakeholders and technical teams. Invest time upfront to ensure everyone shares a common understanding of:

  • The business problem being solved
  • The domain context and constraints
  • Success criteria and expected outcomes

2. Choose Enduring Problems

AI projects require time and patience to complete.

Before beginning any AI project, leaders should be prepared to commit each product team to solving a specific problem for at least a year. Quick wins are rare in AI â€” sustainable success comes from long-term commitment to important problems.

3. Focus on the Problem, Not the Technology

Successful projects are laser-focused on the problem to be solved, not the technology used to solve it.

Resist the temptation to adopt the latest AI trends. Instead:

  • Start with a clear problem statement
  • Select technology that fits the problem
  • Measure success by problem resolution, not technical sophistication

4. Invest in Infrastructure

Up-front investments in infrastructure can reduce the time required to complete AI projects and increase the volume of high-quality data available.

Build robust infrastructure to support:

  • Data governance â€” ensuring data quality, accessibility, and compliance
  • Model deployment â€” enabling smooth transitions from development to production
  • MLOps practices â€” maintaining models effectively over time

5. Understand AI’s Limitations

When considering a potential AI project, leaders need to include technical experts to assess the project’s feasibility.

Not every problem should be solved with AI. Before committing resources:

  • Involve technical experts in early feasibility assessments
  • Honestly evaluate whether AI is the right tool
  • Consider alternative approaches when appropriate

Quick Reference

Challenge Solution
Miscommunication Align technical and business teams on project purpose
Short-term thinking Commit to problems for at least one year
Technology hype Focus on solving real problems
Infrastructure gaps Invest in data governance and deployment infrastructure
Overreach Include technical experts in feasibility assessments

Start Today

The path to AI success isn’t about having the most advanced algorithms â€” it’s about having the right organizational practices, clear problem definitions, and realistic expectations. By implementing these recommendations, organizations can dramatically improve their AI project success rates.
